Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Early Stages of Galaxy Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
While our understanding of galaxy formation and evolution has increased enormously in recent years, some of the most important issues are still largely unknown. In particular, the characterization of low mass, young galaxies in the early universe remains one of the frontiers of astrophysics. Although we cannot analyze their spectra until the advent of future ground and space-based telescopes, we can learn a great deal about their physical conditions using plausible analogs the more nearby universe. The PI will therefore identify and study in detail the youngest and lowest mass galaxies at z~2, a redshift at which the universe was only 20% of its current age, but at which galaxies are still bright enough for detailed study. The PI will lead a comprehensive campaign to measure metallicities and ionization parameters in low-mass galaxies at z~2 from near-infrared spectra; determine the faint-end of the mass-metallicity relation at z~2; and study gravitationally lensed galaxies.

The PI's work will be centered at the University of Wisconsin Milwaukee (UWM), an institution with a large undergraduate population in an urban environment, and one with little previous presence in astronomy. The PI is one of the faculty advisors of the undergraduate astronomy club, which meets weekly and focuses on giving students the opportunity to participate in real astronomical research through radio searches for pulsars. She will also play a leading role in increasing the presence of astronomy at UWM through curriculum development, outreach, and mentoring of students from under-represented populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to study the early stages of the evolution of galaxies, using observations of both distant galaxies in the early universe and rare nearby galaxies with unusual physical conditions that make them similar to more distant galaxies. We carried this out via the analysis of multiple sets of data, focusing particularly on spectroscopic analysis that provides information on the chemical content and ionization state of gas in and around galaxies. We learned new information about the prevalence (or lack thereof) of neutral hydrogen gas in and around the most highly ionized galaxies; this is important because it helps us understand how galaxies carried out the last major phase change in the history of the universe, the transition of the gas surrounding galaxies from neutral to ionized due to the emission of ionizing radiation from galaxies. We also studied the evolution of galaxies in the early universe in detail by taking advantage of the magnification effect of gravitational lensing, obtaining new constraints on the history of star formation in the early universe.

Many students (both graduate and undergraduate) and two postdoctoral scholars were mentored and trained over the course of the project. The Principal Investigator (PI) worked extensively with the undergraduate astronomy club at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, leading discussions of astronomical topics, developing astronomical activities, organizing multiple field trips, and mentoring many students in research, on galaxies as well as data analysis, programming and other topics in astrophysics. The astronomy club also provides regular advising on career options, applying to graduate school and Research Experience for Undergraduates programs. We estimate that more than 100 undergraduate students have participated in astronomy club over the project period, with a significant number of these also participating in research activities. We have recruited students to the astronomy club from a broad range of backgrounds. Two undergraduate students carried out more extensive research projects, and both are now enrolled in astronomy PhD programs. Graduate student and postdoctoral participants have received mentoring in programming, data analysis, scientific communication and writing, and career development. 

Multiple papers have been published over the course of the project, and the PI has presented results at 14 colloquia or seminars and via invited talks at 11 scientific conferences. In 2015, the PI published an invited review article in Nature, providing an overview of one of the topics of this project (?Feedback in low-mass galaxies in the early Universe.? Erb, D.K. 2015, Nature, 523,169). 

The PI has promoted public knowledge of astronomy and galaxies through a variety of outreach activities. In addition to extensive work with the UWM astronomy club, she has given many public talks to a wide variety of audiences, including scouting troops, middle school students, senior citizens, members of local astronomical societies, and visitors to the UWM planetarium and science talk series. The postdocs involved in the project participated in the UWM Coffeeshop Astrophysics program, which gives a monthly astrophysics presentation at a local coffeeshop; these presentations reach up to 200 people each month. In 2016, 2017 and 2019 (with breaks in 2018 and 2020 due to sabbatical and pandemic respectively) the PI and many of the postdocs and students involved in the project presented and astronomy-focused booth at Maker Faire Milwaukee, which has ~40,000 visitors each year.
